title-group.article-title: Institutional Communalism in North Indian Classical Music

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 2012 by the Board of Trustees of the University of Illinois

ref.mixed-citation: For explicit statements of the failure of music institutions to produce performing artists see Daniel Neuman ([1980]1990:199), Dard Neuman (2004:441), Kippen ([1988]2005:35), and Bakhle (2005:253). For a contrasting perspective see Harold Powers (1980), who writes in praise of the successful establishment of institutions of music education, arguing that “music schools have admirably bridged the former social gap between professional musician and cultivated connoisseur, and raised the general status of ‘musician’ as a profession somewhat in so doing” (ibid.:25).

A few short works and brief sections within larger works present glimpses into the world of the educational institutions of Hindustani music, including Erdman (1985), Misra (1985), Alter (1994,2000), Rosse (1995), Kobayashi (2003), and Kippen ([1988]2005).

When the College was founded in 1926 it was known as the All-India College of Hindustani Music. Some six months later, the name was changed to the Marris College of Hindustani Music. The name was later changed again to the Bhatkhande College of Music, and later still to the Bhatkhande Music Institute, Deemed University. For simplicity's sake I will refer to it most often as “the College.”

The changed conditions for hereditary Hindustani musicians have been discussed by scholars including Silver and Burghardt (1976:28), Powers (1980:27), Erdman (1985:116–17), Manuel (1989a:71–72), Daniel Neuman ([1980]1990:20), Qureshi (1991:162;2007:1), Kippen (1997:193;2006:180–81), Misra (2001:xvii), Bakhle (2005:6–7), Slawek (2007:507), and Peterson and Soneji (2008:7–8).

The report was produced by a seven-member committee, including former Chief Justice of the Delhi High Court, Rajinder Sachar, the Chairperson whose name has come to stand for the report. After some twenty months of exhaustive research, the committee presented its findings in the form of a 424-page report to the office of the Prime Minister of India in 2006 (see Sachar et al.2006).
For alternative approaches to employing Althusser's theory of ideological apparatuses in music studies see Garofalo (1987:86–88), Mowitt (2002:42–58), and Middleton (2006:232–35).

Several scholars have suggested that Althusser's theory of ideology presents a sealed system, foreclosing the possibility of resistance by the dominated classes. For insightful criticism in this regard see Hall (1985), Eagleton (1991), Ricoeur (1994), and Pecheux (1994).

While this essay addresses the Lucknow gharana of sarod and sitar, the city is also well known for its tabla and kathak dance gharanas. For significant works on those gharanas see Kippen ([1988]2005) and Walker (2004), respectively.

From the time of its establishment as the capital of the Awadh region in 1775, the city of Lucknow became a magnet for musicians who streamed into the city in search of patronage. In the nineteenth century, Lucknow became North India's premiere musical center (see Kippen [1988]2005:2; Manuel
1991:350), as well as its “largest and most prosperous” city outside of the new British colonial centers of Calcutta, Bombay, and Madras ( Oldenburg
1984:3–4).
For the story behind Bhatkhande's decision to join with Bali in establishing the College in Lucknow see Singh (1952) and Bakhle (2005:195–200).

The precise date of the opening of the College remains slightly mysterious. Mutatkar suggests July 1926 (2001:22), while Bakhle gives September 1926 (2005:201). In a letter dated July 29, 1926, Bali writes that while “The committee wanted to open it from July 15,” the opening had been postponed until August 10 (1926b:31). The College Progress Report produced in 1940 covers the period from from August 1926 to December 1939, suggesting an August grand opening ( Bali
1940). It seems clear, however, that expenses for the College, including payment to instructors, began in July 1926 ( Bali
1926b).

Bali describes Abid Husain in a handwritten note as “a tabla player of all India fame, awarded a gold medal, first prize in [the] 4th All India music conference” (1927:32). According to Misra, Abid Husain was born in 1867 and died in 1936 (1985:40–41). For Abid Husain's great significance within the Lucknow tabla gharana see Kippen ([1988]2005:74–78).

As genealogical work by Miner ([1993]1997), McNeil (2004), and Tamori (2008) reveals, the stylistic and hereditary lineage known today as the Lucknow gharana resulted from the intertwining in the early twentieth century of two distinct families of sarod players who trace their ancestry to the districts of Shahjahanpur and Bulandshahr, about 100 miles and 250 miles northwest of Lucknow, respectively. Both of these lineages—sometimes known as the Shahjahanpur gharana and the Bulandshahr gharana—ultimately lead back to Afghanistan, where their Pathan progenitors were players of the Afghani rabab. In the mid-twentieth century, the Lucknow gharana also absorbed a sitar tradition sometimes termed the Kalpi gharana after the birthplace of its nineteenth-century founder, Azam Khan. Thus, the present-day Lucknow gharana could be said to represent the blending of the Shahjahanpur, Bulandshahr, and Kalpi gharanas, though certainly not in equal proportions.

First-cousin marriage, permissible in Islam, was pervasive among families of Muslim hereditary musicians, thus explaining Sakhawat Husain Khan's dual familial relationship to his teacher, “Kaukab” Khan.
This translation from the Devanagari text is my own.

Yusuf Ali Khan inherited the traditions of Azam Khan, a sitarist, bin player, and dhrupad singer who moved from his home in Kalpi (about 100 miles southwest of Lucknow) to serve as court musician for the Maharana of Khajurgaon, a small principality in the district of Rai Bareli (about 50 miles south of Lucknow). In the late nineteenth century, Azam Khan's son, Abdul Ghani Khan, adopted Yusuf Ali Khan as an unrelated disciple (See Miner [1993]1997:142).

While these conferences were not overtly political, both Trasoff (1999:143) and Bakhle (2005:180) have noted that they shared important features with the Indian National Congress, the primary political body seeking a national solution to the problem of British occupation in the early decades of the twentieth century.

Bali's invocation of “the last 60 years” likely refers to the period beginning after the rebellion of 1857–58 when the British strengthened their colonial rule, now under the direct auspices of the royal crown. As noted above, Bali connects the “fall” of the Hindustani music tradition directly to British colonialism.

In 1924, Rai Umanath Bali's nephew (though three years his senior), Dr. Rai Rajeshwar Bali, was appointed Minister of Education for the United Provinces, and would go on to become the President of the Managing Committee of the College from 1929 to 1943. It was through his connection to the British Governor of the United Provinces, Sir William Marris, that the College came to be redubbed the Marris College of Hindustani Music some six months after its grand opening ( Singh
1952:1).
